title: 111_s1371
content: The Act is titled the "Clean Renewable Water Supply Bond Act of 2009" and introduces the creation of Clean Renewable Water Supply Bonds under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Clean Renewable Water Supply Bonds are defined as bonds issued for capital expenditures by qualified borrowers for qualified projects, issued by a qualified issuer, designated for this purpose, and allocated by the Secretary before 2019. The national clean renewable water supply bond limitation for each calendar year before 2019 ranges from $0 in 2009 to $500,000,000 in 2014. Unused allocations within a 6-month period will increase the limitation for the next application period. The national clean renewable water supply bond limitation for 2013 is $250,000,000, increasing annually to $1,750,000,000 in 2018. The Secretary allocates the limitation among qualified projects through a notice soliciting applications from qualified issuers. The Secretary allocates the national clean renewable water supply bond limitation to qualified projects on a first-come, first-served basis after a 3-month application period. No allocation is made without necessary certifications regarding regulatory approvals. The Secretary allocates the national clean renewable water supply bond limitation to qualified projects based on certifications of regulatory approvals. The allocation is limited to 60 percent for any calendar year. The national clean renewable water supply bond limitation allocates funds to large projects delivering over 10,000,000 gallons of water per day, with restrictions on the percentage allocated to any single project. The national clean renewable water supply bond limitation allocates funds to large projects delivering over 10,000,000 gallons of water per day, with restrictions on the percentage allocated to any single project. An exception allows unallocated portions to carry over to the next calendar year if the limitation exceeds the amount allocated. The clean renewable water supply bond has a maturity limitation of 20 years and can be used to refinance qualified projects. The term 'governmental body' is defined for this purpose. The term 'governmental body' includes State, Indian tribal governments, or political subdivisions. 'Local water company' refers to entities providing water service to the public. 'Qualified borrower' is a governmental body or local water company. 'Qualified desalination facility' produces new water supplies by desalinating seawater, groundwater, or surface water with chlorides or total dissolved solids. The term 'qualified groundwater remediation facility' refers to facilities reclaiming contaminated groundwater for potable use. 'Qualified issuer' includes governmental bodies or States/political entities. The term 'qualified project' refers to facilities owned by a qualified borrower, including desalination, recycled water, and groundwater remediation facilities, or related facilities. The term 'qualified recycled water facility' refers to wastewater treatment or distribution facilities that exceed Clean Water Act requirements and other water pollution control standards. The project must comply with regulations for minimizing environmental impact to be considered a qualified project. The term 'qualified recycled water facility' refers to wastewater treatment or distribution facilities that exceed Clean Water Act requirements and other water pollution control standards. It is used to reclaim wastewater produced by the general public for beneficial purposes that would otherwise require potable water supplies. Reclaimed wastewater cannot be used to supplement potable water supplies for certain purposes, such as discharging into waterways, restoring habitat, providing once-through cooling for electric generation, or intentionally introducing into groundwater. Regulations will be prescribed by the Secretary. The Secretary will prescribe regulations to minimize the environmental impact of qualified facilities. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include adding a clean renewable water supply bond. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include a clean renewable water supply bond for specified purposes. Section 54G introduces Clean Renewable Water Supply Bonds, effective for obligations issued after December 31, 2008.
